A network administrator needs to be able to securely connect to a local router from within the office.
Which of the following protocols should the administrator ensure is enabled on the router?

Secure Shell
Protocol
Secure Shell is a cryptographic network protocol for operating network services securely over an unsecured network. Typical applications include remote command-line, login, and remote command execution, but any network service can be secured with SSH.

Which of the following types of partitioning should be performed to give the customer full use of the 3 TB drive?

discussion.content: Why is this not a phishing attempt? Spoofing is a method of delivering sensitive data not mostly through your network addresses than emails, while phishing is a method of retrieving sensitive data by email

comments.content: You are correct in that it is clearly a phishing attempt, i guess they want spoofing because "The email came from the help desks email address" so the email address was spoofed. Spoofing just refers to changing something that tells devices who/where you are, it could be spoofing your email address, IP, MAC, etc.
Agreed, the email is impersonating the help desk email address. The impersonation of a known legitimate source points to the spoofing definition instead of phishing

discussion.content:
A is correct 

Phishing is a type of social engineering attack often used to steal user data, including login credentials and credit card numbers. It occurs when an attacker, masquerading as a trusted entity, dupes a victim into opening an email, instant message, or text message.

Spoofing is the act of disguising a communication from an unknown source as being from a known, trusted source. ... Spoofing is often the way a bad actor gains access in order to execute a larger cyber attack such as an advanced persistent threat or a man-in-the-middle attack.

comments.content: read the question, it says the email came from the help desk...

discussion.content:
Agree this is spoofing..per Meyers
Spoofing is the process of pretending to be someone or something
you are not by placing false information into your packets. Any data sent on a
network can be spoofed. Here are a few quick examples of commonly
spoofed data:
• Source MAC address and IP address, to make you think a packet came
from somewhere else
• E-mail address, to make you think an e-mail came from somewhere
else
• Web address, to make you think you are on a Web page you are not on
• User name, to make you think a certain user is contacting you when in
reality it’s someone completely different
Generally, spoofing isn’t so much a threat as it is a tool to make threats. If
you spoof my e-mail address, for example, that by itself isn’t a threat. If you
use my e-mail address to pretend to be me, however, and to ask my
employees to send in their user names and passwords for network login?
That’s clearly a threat. 
Messer
2.5 - Spoofing
Spoofing
• Pretend to be something you aren’t
• Fake web server, fake DNS server, etc.
• Email address spoofing
• The sending address of an email isn’t really the sender

Selected Answer: D
This is email spoofing.

Selected Answer: D
Spoofing is the right answer

best way to remember spoofing is to remember that the S stands for spy(from team fortress 2)...

The correct answer is Spoofing. Spoofing is identity theft where a person is trying to use the identity of a legitimate user. Phishing is where a person steals the sensitive information of the user like bank account details. Spoofing can be phishing in part. Phishing is not a part of spoofing.

questions.question_text:
Users notify the help desk of an email that was just received. The email came from the help desk's email address and asked the users to click on an embedded link.
This email is BEST described as:

discussion.content: FYI they have new test questions because most of these questions were not on my test, however i was still able to pass with everything that I learned.

So just to make it clear you all, this message is displayed by the malware: "There are 1033 infected files on this computer. Click here to disinfect." 

"Click here" refers to the link that is blocked by the corporate content filter, therefore you should not request filter exception, otherwise you would just go to an infected website. D = INCORRECT

You do not backup during malware infection. C = INCORRECT

YOU DO NOT DISABLE SECURITY SOFTWARE when you see a message like that. B = INCORRECT

That gives you the correct = A
Spoofing not phishinand it is a spoofing scenario very spoofing question lol

comments.content: so youre implying that a rogue antivirus is technically spoofing?

discussion.content:
A – It would probably only take about 15 minutes or less to get a list of startup items and services from a known clean image and from the problem workstation. Comparing the two lists would take maybe 15 minutes or so – removing the the alien items from the workstation would probably take less than 10 minutes. Running an anti-malware scan would likely take less than an hour -- so MINIMAL impact to the user.
Not C - First of all, in backing up the user’s files you may be backing up the virus that caused the problem in the first place. You would need to restore the user’s files from a backup taken prior to the virus. And from my personal experience in IT support, restoring a system from an image (usually via PXE over the network) can take up to an hour or more. If roaming profiles are not being used then all of the user’s profile settings (desktop, favorites, downloads, etc) will be lost – so these things together are not a MINIMAL impact to the user.]

Its a clear C...

questions.question_text:
A technician responds to a call from a user who claims to have a virus on a workstation. The technician observes the following notification from the system tray:
There are 1033 infected files on this computer. Click here to disinfect.
The link is blocked by the corporate content filter and displays a message stating the site contains known malware.
Which of the following should the technician complete to secure the computer with MINIMAL impact to the user?

choices.A: Compare the startup items and services to a known clean image, and remove any startup items not found in the other image. Run an anti-malware scan.
choices.D: Request a content filter exception to allow access to the link from the notification. Once available, follow the instructions on the linked site.
choices.B: Validate that the alerts are false positives, and disable security software on the workstation to prevent further false notifications.
choices.C: Back up the user's files. Restore the system to the original system image designated by corporate IT policies. Restore the user's files.

comments.content: Shared inbox folders is a shared directory

discussion.content: If its a shared inbox, not a shared directory, then should the answer not be D ?

comments.content:
I'm with these guys/gals. Unless otherwise specified, most material here is Microsoft based. In addition to their reasoning, with an Exchange server shared inbox you change it's permissions, not the users.

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/collaboration-exo/shared-mailboxes

Agreed, I am choosing C too : 

OBJ-3.2: While Edward was on vacation, the network file share's permissions have likely been modified. Based on the fact that Edward's account is connected to the domain and can send/receive emails, it cannot be his user account's permissions causing the issue. The internet security options would also prevent him from sending/receiving mail, so that can be eliminated. Even if the operating system were updated, that would not affect the shared inboxes since they reside on the network file shares and not Edward's computer.

discussion.content:
So I can definitely see both C and D being correct. I answered C. My thinking as to why C is correct is that the user can still send/receive emails (so no problem with user account permissions) but not being able to see a shared folder can result from that folder having having its permissions manually changed and the users account was missed from the update (in case of a SOHO setup, with only a few users) OR the user was added to a Group that does not have allow permissions for the shared folder so is denied access (because conflicting policies default to implicit deny). In these cases changing the folder share permissions would correct the problem such as “allow” the user directly or create an exception/workaround to the implicit deny for their account. These would be classified as folder permissions problems, not user account permissions.

Any thoughts about my argument?

Selected Answer: C
is it C or D?
At the beginning we have "A user's corporate email". The answer should be C
He went for vacation, and most company disable user account until someone is back for security reason. I'm going with D.

Because its a shared inbox so the correct answer is:
D. The user account permissions have changed
User gets access to shared inbox through permissions in group policy or directly in exchange. Correct answer is D.

comments.content: Agreed, but this is CompTIA. They have many inaccurate answers but 3 other exam prep sites state that C is the answer. Just have to remember that isn't accurate in the real world
Totally agree with you . The answer should be D

questions.question_text:
A user's corporate email is missing the shared inbox folders that were present before the user went on vacation. The technician verifies the user is connected to the domain and can still send and receive email.
Which of the following is MOST likely causing the missing folders issue?

choices.D: The user account permissions have changed
choices.A: The Internet security options have changed
choices.B: The operating system updates have changed
choices.C: The network directory permissions have changed
